{{redirects here|Rafting event|using rafts as a sport or pleasure event|Rafting}}
'''Oceanic dispersal''' is a type of [[biological dispersal]] that occurs when terrestrial organisms transfer from one land mass to another by way of a sea crossing. Often this occurs via large rafts of floating vegetation such as are sometimes seen floating down major rivers in the tropics and washing out to sea, occasionally with animals trapped on them.<ref name=Mittermeier>{{cite book | last = Mittermeier | first = R.A. | authorlink = Russell Mittermeier | title = Lemurs of Madagascar | edition = 2nd | publisher = Conservation International | year = 2006 | pages = 24–26 | isbn=1-881173-88-7|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Dispersal via such a raft is sometimes referred to as a "rafting event".
Colonization of land masses by plants can also occur via long-distance oceanic dispersal of floating seeds.<ref name="Won2">{{cite journal | last1 = Won | first1 = H. | last2 = Renner | first2 = S. S. | year = 2006 | title = Dating dispersal and radiation in the gymnosperm ''Gnetum'' (Gnetales) – clock calibration when outgroup relationships are uncertain | url = | journal = Systematic Biology | volume = 55 | issue = 4| pages = 610–622 | doi = 10.1080/10635150600812619 | pmid=16969937}}</ref>
==History== Rafting has played an important role in the colonization of isolated land masses by mammals. Prominent examples include [[Madagascar]], which has been isolated for ~120 million years ([[Year#SI prefix multipliers|Ma]]), and [[South America]], which was isolated for much of the [[Cenozoic]]. Both land masses, for example, appear to have received their [[primate]]s by this mechanism. According to genetic evidence, the common ancestor of the [[lemur]]s of [[Madagascar]] appears to have crossed the [[Mozambique Channel]] by rafting between 50 and 60 Ma ago.<ref name=Roos>{{cite journal | first = Christian | last = Roos |author2=Schmitz, Jürgen |author3=Zischler, Hans | title = Primate jumping genes elucidate strepsirrhine phylogeny | journal = PNAS | date = July 2004 | volume = 101 | pages = 10650–10654 | url = http://www.pnas.org/content/101/29/10650.full.pdf | format = PDF | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0403852101 | pmid = 15249661 | issue = 29 | pmc = 489989 | bibcode=2004PNAS..10110650R}}</ref><ref name=Sellers>{{cite web | url = http://homepage.mac.com/wis/Personal/lectures/human-origins/PrimateEvolution.pdf | title = Primate Evolution | accessdate = 2008-10-23 | last = Sellers | first = Bill | date = 2000-10-20 | format = PDF | publisher = [[University of Edinburgh]] | pages = 13–17}}</ref><ref name = "Ali&Huber">{{Cite journal | last = Ali | first = J. R. |author2=Huber, M. | title = Mammalian biodiversity on Madagascar controlled by ocean currents | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume = 463 | issue = 4 Feb. 2010 | pages = 653–656 | publisher = [[Nature Publishing Group]] | date = 2010-01-20 | url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nature08706.html | doi = 10.1038/nature08706 | accessdate = 2010-01-20 | pmid = 20090678 | bibcode=2010Natur.463..653A}}</ref> Likewise, the [[New World monkey]]s are thought to have originated in [[Africa]] and rafted to [[South America]] by the [[Oligocene]], when the continents were much closer than they are today.<ref name=Sellers/> Madagascar also appears to have received its [[Tenrecidae|tenrecs]] (25–42 Ma ago), [[Nesomyidae|nesomyid]] rodents (20–24 Ma ago) and [[Eupleridae|euplerid]] carnivorans (19–26 Ma ago) by this route<ref name = "Ali&Huber"/> and South America its [[Caviomorpha|caviomorph]] rodents (over 30 Ma ago).<ref>{{cite journal | title=Recent advances in South American mammalian paleontology |author1=Flynn, J. J. |author2=Wyss, A. R. | journal=Trends in Ecology and Evolution | volume=13 | issue=11| pages=449–454| year=1998 | doi= 10.1016/S0169-5347(98)01457-8 | pmid=21238387 }}</ref><ref name = SciAm>{{cite journal| title=South America's Missing Mammals |author1=Flynn, John J. |author2=Wyss, André R. |author3=Charrier, Reynaldo|author-link3=Reynaldo Charrier | journal=[[Scientific American]]| volume=| issue= May| pages= 68–75| year= 2007 | url= http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=south-americas-missing-mammals }}</ref> [[simian|Simian primates]] (ancestral to monkeys) and [[Hystricognathi|hystricognath]] rodents (ancestral to caviomorphs) are believed to have previously rafted from Asia to Africa about 40 Ma ago.<ref name = "Chaimanee">{{Cite journal | last1 = Chaimanee | first1 = Y. | last2 = Chavasseau | first2 = O. | last3 = Beard | first3 = K. C. | last4 = Kyaw | first4 = A. A. | last5 = Soe | first5 = A. N. | last6 = Sein | first6 = C. | last7 = Lazzari | first7 = V. | last8 = Marivaux | first8 = L. | last9 = Marandat | first9 = B. | last10 = Swe | first10 = M. | last11 = Rugbumrung | first11 = M. | last12 = Lwin | first12 = T. | last13 = Valentin | first13 = X. | last14 = Zin-Maung-Maung-Thein | last15 = Jaeger | first15 = J. -J. | title = Late Middle Eocene primate from Myanmar and the initial anthropoid colonization of Africa | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1200644109 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 109 | issue = 26 | pages = 10293 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22665790| pmc = 3387043| ref = harv | bibcode = 2012PNAS..10910293C }}</ref>
Among reptiles, [[Brachylophus|several iguanid species]] in the South Pacific have been hypothesized to be descended from iguanas that rafted {{convert|10000|km}} from Central or South America<ref name="Gibbons">{{Cite journal | last = Gibbons | first = J. R. H. | title = The Biogeography of ''Brachylophus'' (Iguanidae) including the Description of a New Species, ''B. vitiensis'', from Fiji | journal = Journal of Herpetology | volume = 15 | issue = 3 | pages = 255–273 | publisher = Society for the Study of Amphibians and Reptiles | location = | date = Jul 31, 1981 | issn = | doi = 10.2307/1563429| id = | jstor=1563429}}</ref> (an alternative theory involves dispersal of a putative now-extinct iguana lineage from Australia or Asia<ref name="Noonan">{{cite journal|author1=Noonan, B.P. |author2=Sites, J. W., Jr. |date= 2009-11-24|title=Tracing the origins of iguanid lizards and boine snakes of the Pacific|publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]]|pages=61–72|doi=10.1086/648607|volume=175 |pmid=19929634 |issue=1 |journal=[[The American Naturalist]]}}</ref>). Similarly, a number of [[clade]]s of American [[gecko]]s seem to have rafted over from Africa during both the Paleogene and Neogene.<ref name = "Gamble2010">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1420-9101.2010.02184.x| title = Coming to America: Multiple origins of New World geckos| journal = Journal of Evolutionary Biology| volume = 24| issue = 2| pages = 231–244| date = 2010-12-03| last1 = Gamble | first1 = T.| last2 = Bauer | first2 = A. M.| last3 = Colli | first3 = G. R.| last4 = Greenbaum | first4 = E.| last5 = Jackman | first5 = T. R.| last6 = Vitt | first6 = L. J.| last7 = Simons | first7 = A. M.| url = http://www.tc.umn.edu/~gambl007/publications/Gamble_etal_2011_jeb.pdf | pmid=21126276 | pmc=3075428}}</ref> [[Skink]]s of the related genera ''[[Mabuya]]'' and ''[[Trachylepis]]'' also apparently both floated across the Atlantic from Africa to South America and [[Fernando de Noronha]], respectively, during the last 9 Ma.<ref name = "Carranza">{{cite journal | last = Carranza | first = S. |author2=Arnold, N. E. | title = Investigating the origin of transoceanic distributions: mtDNA shows ''Mabuya'' lizards (Reptilia, Scincidae) crossed the Atlantic twice | journal = Systematics and Biodiversity | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages = 275–282 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | date = 2003-08-05 | url = http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=168963 | doi= 10.1017/S1477200003001099 | accessdate = 2008-04-04}}</ref> Skinks from the same group have also rafted from Africa to [[Cape Verde]], Madagascar, the [[Seychelles]], the [[Comoros]] and [[Socotra]].<ref name = "Carranza"/> (Among lizards, skinks and geckos seem especially capable of surviving long transoceanic journeys.<ref name = "Carranza"/>) Surprisingly, even burrowing [[amphisbaenia]]ns<ref name = "Vidal2007">{{Cite journal | last1 = Vidal | first1 = N. | last2 = Azvolinsky | first2 = A. | last3 = Cruaud | first3 = C. | last4 = Hedges | first4 = S. B. | title = Origin of tropical American burrowing reptiles by transatlantic rafting | doi = 10.1098/rsbl.2007.0531 | journal = Biology Letters | volume = 4 | issue = 1 | pages = 115–118 | date = 2007-12-11 | pmid = 18077239| pmc =2412945 }}</ref> and [[blind snake]]s<ref name = "Vidal2010">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1098/rsbl.2010.0220| title = Blindsnake evolutionary tree reveals long history on Gondwana| journal = Biology Letters| volume = 6| issue = 4| pages = 558–561| date = 2010-03-31| last1 = Vidal | first1 = N.| last2 = Marin | first2 = J.| last3 = Morini | first3 = M.| last4 = Donnellan | first4 = S.| last5 = Branch | first5 = W. R.| last6 = Thomas | first6 = R.| last7 = Vences | first7 = M.| last8 = Wynn | first8 = A.| last9 = Cruaud | first9 = C.| last10 = Hedges | first10 = S. B. | pmid=20356885 | pmc=2936224}}</ref> appear to have rafted from Africa to South America.
An example of a bird that is thought to have reached its present location by rafting is the weak-flying South American [[hoatzin]], whose ancestors apparently floated over from Africa.<ref name = "Mayr2011">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1007/s00114-011-0849-1| title = Out of Africa: Fossils shed light on the origin of the hoatzin, an iconic Neotropic bird| journal = Naturwissenschaften| volume = 98| issue = 11| pages = 961–966| date = 2011-10-01| last1 = Mayr | first1 = G. | last2 = Alvarenga | first2 = H. | last3 = Mourer-Chauviré | first3 = C. C. | pmid=21964974| bibcode = 2011NW.....98..961M}}</ref>
Colonization of groups of islands can occur by an [[Iteration|iterative]] rafting process sometimes called [[island hopping]]. Such a process appears to have played a role, for example, in the colonization of the [[Caribbean]] by [[Mammals of the Caribbean|mammals of South American origin]] (including caviomorphs and monkeys).<ref name = "Hedges2006">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.3417/0026-6493(2006)93[231:POTAAO]2.0.CO;2| title = Paleogeography of the Antilles and Origin of West Indian Terrestrial Vertebrates1| journal = [[Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden]]| volume = 93| issue = 2| pages = 231–244| year = 2006| last1 = Hedges | first1 = S. Blair}}</ref>
A remarkable example of iterative rafting has been proposed for spiders of the genus ''[[List of Anyphaenidae species#Amaurobioides|Amaurobioides]]''.<ref name = "Kukso2016">{{cite web | url = https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/seafaring-spiders-made-it-around-the-world-in-8-million-years/ | title = Seafaring Spiders Made It around the World—in 8 Million Years | last = Kukso | first = F. | date = 2016-11-08 | website = [[Scientific American]] | access-date = 2016-11-10}}</ref><ref name="Kuntner2016">{{cite journal|last1= Kuntner|first1=M.|last2= Ceccarelli|first2=F. S.|last3= Opell|first3=B. D.|last4= Haddad|first4=C. R.|last5= Raven|first5=Robert J.|last6= Soto|first6=E. M.|last7= Ramírez|first7=M. J.|title=Around the World in Eight Million Years: Historical Biogeography and Evolution of the Spray Zone Spider ''Amaurobioides'' (Araneae: Anyphaenidae)|journal=PLOS One|volume= 11|issue= 10|date= 2016-10-12|pages= e0163740|doi= 10.1371/journal.pone.0163740|pmid=27732621|pmc=5061358|bibcode=2016PLoSO..1163740C}}</ref> Members of this genus inhabit coastal sites and build silken cells which they seal at high tide; however, they do not [[Ballooning (spider)|balloon]]. DNA sequence analysis suggests that ancestors of the genus dispersed from southern South America to South Africa about 10 million years (Ma) ago, where the most [[Basal (phylogenetics)|basal]] clade is found; subsequent rafting events then took the genus eastward with the [[Antarctic Circumpolar Current]] to Australia, then to New Zealand and finally to Chile by about 2 Ma ago.<ref name="Kuntner2016" /> Another example among spiders is the species ''[[Moggridgea rainbowi]]'', the only Australian member of a genus otherwise endemic to Africa, with a divergence date of 2 to 16 Ma ago.<ref name="Kuntner2017">{{cite journal|last1=Kuntner|first1=M.|last2=Harrison|first2=S. E.|last3=Harvey|first3=M. S.|last4=Cooper|first4=S. J. B.|last5=Austin|first5=A. D.|last6=Rix|first6=M. G.|title=Across the Indian Ocean: A remarkable example of trans-oceanic dispersal in an austral mygalomorph spider|journal=PLOS One|volume=12|issue=8|year=2017|page=e0180139|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0180139|bibcode=2017PLoSO..1280139H}}</ref>
However, oceanic dispersal of terrestrial species may not always take the form of rafting; in some cases, swimming or simply floating may suffice. Tortoises of the genus ''[[Chelonoidis]]'' arrived in South America from Africa in the Oligocene;<ref name = "Le et al.">{{cite journal | last = Le | first = M. |author2=Raxworthy, C. J. |author3=McCord, W. P. |author4=Mertz, L. | title = A molecular phylogeny of tortoises (Testudines: Testudinidae) based on mitochondrial and nuclear genes | journal = Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution | volume = 40 | issue = 2 | pages = 517–531 | date = 2006-05-05 | url = https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1055790306000856 | doi = 10.1016/j.ympev.2006.03.003 | pmid = 16678445 }}</ref> they were probably aided by their ability to float with their heads up, and to survive up to six months without food or fresh water.<ref name = "Le et al."/> South American tortoises then went on to colonize the [[West Indies]] and [[Galápagos tortoise|Galápagos Islands]]. The dispersal of [[anthracothere]]s from Asia to Africa about 40 Ma ago,<ref name = "Chaimanee"/> and the much more recent dispersal of [[hippopotamus|hippo]]s (relatives and probably descendants of anthracotheres) from Africa to Madagascar may have occurred by floating or swimming.<ref name = "Ali&Huber"/>
==Observation== The first documented example of colonization of a land mass by rafting occurred in the aftermath of hurricanes [[Hurricane Luis|Luis]] and [[Hurricane Marilyn|Marilyn]] in the [[Caribbean]] in 1995. A raft of uprooted trees carrying fifteen or more [[green iguana]]s was observed by fishermen landing on the east side of [[Anguilla]] – an island where they had never before been recorded.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lawrence|first=E.|date=1998-10-15|title=Iguanas ride the waves|journal=Nature|doi=10.1038/news981015-3}}</ref> The iguanas had apparently been caught on the trees and rafted two hundred miles across the ocean from [[Guadeloupe]], where they are indigenous.<ref name="Censky1998">{{cite journal|last1= Censky|first1=E. J.|last2= Hodge|first2=K.|last3= Dudley|first3= J.|journal= Nature|title= Over-water dispersal of lizards due to hurricanes|volume= 395|issue= 6702|date= 1998-10-08|page= 556|doi=10.1038/26886|bibcode= 1998Natur.395..556C}}</ref><ref name="Yoon1998">{{cite news | last = Yoon | first = C. K. | title = ''Hapless iguanas float away and voyage grips biologists'' | publisher = The New York Times | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/08/us/hapless-iguanas-float-away-and-voyage-grips-biologists.html | date = 1998-10-08}}</ref> Examination of the weather patterns and ocean currents indicated that they had probably spent three weeks at sea before landfall.<ref name="Yoon1998"/> This colony began breeding on the new island within two years of its arrival.<ref name="Yoon1998"/>
The advent of human civilization has created opportunities for organisms to raft on floating artifacts, which may be more durable than natural floating objects. This phenomenon was noted following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|2011 Tōhoku tsunami]] in Japan, with about 300 species found to have been carried on debris by the [[North Pacific Current]] to the west coast of North America (although no colonizations have been detected thus far).<ref name="Chown2017">{{cite journal|last1= Chown|first1=S. L.|title= Tsunami debris spells trouble|journal= Science|volume= 357|issue= 6358|year= 2017|pages= 1356–1356|doi= 10.1126/science.aao5677|bibcode= 2017Sci...357.1356C}}</ref><ref name="Carlton2017">{{cite journal|last1= Carlton|first1=J. T.|last2= Chapman|first2=J. W.|last3= Geller|first3=J. B.|last4= Miller|first4=J. A.|last5= Carlton|first5=D. A.|last6= McCuller|first6=M. I.|last7= Treneman|first7=N. C.|last8= Steves|first8=B. P.|last9= Ruiz|first9=G. M.|title= Tsunami-driven rafting: Transoceanic species dispersal and implications for marine biogeography|journal= Science|volume= 357|issue= 6358|year= 2017|pages= 1402–1406|doi= 10.1126/science.aao1498|pmid=28963256|bibcode=2017Sci...357.1402C}}</ref>

{{Redirect|Skinner box|the ska band|Skinnerbox}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2010}} [[Image:Skinner box scheme 01.png|right|thumb|300px|Skinner box]] [[Image:Skinner box photo 02.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Skinner box with 2 respond levers, 2 cue lights, 1 electrified floor, 1 house light and 1 speaker are above the cage]] An '''operant conditioning chamber''' (also known as the '''Skinner box''') is a [[laboratory equipment|laboratory apparatus]] used to study animal [[experimental analysis of behavior|behavior]]. The operant conditioning chamber was created by [[B. F. Skinner]] while he was a graduate student at [[Harvard University]]. It may have been inspired by [[Jerzy Konorski|Jerzy Konorski's]] studies. It is used to study both [[operant conditioning]] and [[classical conditioning]].<ref>{{cite book|last=R.Carlson|first=Neil|title=Psychology-the science of behavior|year=2009|publisher=Pearson Education Canada; 4th edition|location=U.S|isbn=978-0-205-64524-4|page=207}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Krebs |first1=John R. |title=Animal behaviour: From Skinner box to the field |journal=Nature |volume=304 |issue=5922 |pages=117 |year=1983 |pmid=6866102 |doi=10.1038/304117a0 |bibcode=1983Natur.304..117K }}</ref>
Skinner created the operant chamber as a variation of the [[Edward Thorndike#Connectionism|puzzle box]] originally created by [[Edward Thorndike]].<ref>{{cite book |first1=Daniel L. |last1=Schacter |first2=Daniel T. |last2=Gilbert |first3=Daniel M. |last3=Wegner |first4=Matthew K. |last4=Nock |year=2014 |chapter=B. F. Skinner: The Role of Reinforcement and Punishment |pages=278–80 |title=Psychology |edition=3rd |publisher=Macmillan |isbn=978-1-4641-5528-4 }}</ref>
==Purpose==
An operant conditioning chamber permits experimenters to study behavior conditioning (training) by teaching a subject animal to perform certain actions (like pressing a lever) in response to specific stimuli, such as a light or sound signal. When the subject correctly performs the behavior, the chamber mechanism delivers food or another reward. In some cases, the mechanism delivers a punishment for incorrect or missing responses. For instance, to test how operant conditioning works for certain invertebrates, such as fruit flies, psychologists use a device known as a "heat box". Essentially this takes up the same form as the Skinner box, but the box is composed of two sides: one side that can undergo temperature change and the other that does not. As soon as the invertebrate crosses over to the side that can undergo a temperature change, the area is heated up. Eventually, the invertebrate will be conditioned to stay on the side that does not undergo a temperature change. This goes to the extent that even when the temperature is turned to its lowest point, the fruit fly will still refrain from approaching that area of the heat box.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brembs|first=Björn|title=Operant conditioning in invertebrates|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0959438803001570|journal=Current Opinion in Neurobiology|volume=13|issue=6|pages=710–717|doi=10.1016/j.conb.2003.10.002}}</ref> These types of apparatuses allow experimenters to perform studies in conditioning and training through reward/punishment mechanisms.
==Structure== The structure forming the shell of a chamber is a box large enough to easily accommodate the animal being used as a subject. (Commonly used model animals include [[rodent]]s—usually [[lab rat]]s—[[pigeon]]s, and [[primate]]s). It is often [[soundproofing|sound-proof]] and light-proof to avoid distracting stimuli.
Operant chambers have at least one operandum (or "manipulandum"), and often two or more, that can automatically detect the occurrence of a [[behavior]]al response or action. Typical operanda for primates and rats are response levers; if the subject presses the lever, the opposite end moves and closes a switch that is monitored by a computer or other programmed device. Typical operanda for pigeons and other [[bird]]s are [[telegraph key|response keys]] with a switch that closes if the bird pecks at the key with sufficient [[force]]. The other minimal requirement of a conditioning chamber is that it has a means of delivering a primary reinforcer (a reward, such as food, etc.) or [[unconditioned stimulus]] like food (usually pellets) or water. It can also register the delivery of a conditioned reinforcer, such as an LED (see Jackson & Hackenberg 1996 in the ''Journal of the Experimental Analysis of Behavior'' for example) signal as a "token".
Despite such a simple configuration, one operandum and one feeder, it is possible to investigate many psychological phenomena. Modern operant conditioning chambers typically have many operanda, like many response levers, two or more feeders, and a variety of devices capable of generating many [[stimulus (physiology)|stimuli]], including lights, sounds, music, figures, and drawings. Some configurations use an LCD panel for the computer generation of a variety of visual stimuli.
Some operant chambers can also have electrified nets or floors so that shocks can be given to the animals; or lights of different colors that give information about when the food is available. Although the use of shock is not unheard of, approval may be needed in countries that regulate experimentation on animals.
==Research impact== Operant conditioning chambers have become common in a variety of research disciplines including [[behavioral pharmacology]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}} The results of these experiments inform many disciplines outside of psychology, such as [[behavioral economics]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}}
An [[urban legend]] spread concerning Skinner putting his daughter through an experiment such as this, causing great controversy. His daughter later debunked this.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/one-man-and-a-baby-box/|title=B.F. Skinner Raised His Daughter in a Skinner Box?|last=Mikkelson|first=David|date=11 March 2014|department=Fact Check|website=[[Snopes.com]]|archive-url=https://archive.is/20180505120609/https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/one-man-and-a-baby-box/|archive-date=5 May 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=5 May 2018}}</ref>
==Commercial applications== [[Slot machine]]s and [[Massive multiplayer online game|online games]] are sometimes cited<ref>{{Cite news|title=Behavioral game design|author=Hopson, J.|date=April 2001|journal=Gamasutra|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=Behavioral+Game+Design}}</ref> as examples of human devices that use sophisticated operant schedules of reinforcement to reward repetitive actions.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Psychology: A modular approach to mind and behavior|author=Dennis Coon|year=2005|publisher=Thomson Wadsworth|isbn=0-534-60593-1|pages=278–279|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=018X76Gn_T0C&pg=PA278&lpg=PA278}}</ref>
[[Social networking service]]s such as [[Google]], [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]] have been identified as using the techniques, critics use terms such as ''Skinnerian Marketing''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Davidow|first1=Bill|title=Skinner Marketing: We're the Rats, and Facebook Likes Are the Reward|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2013/06/skinner-marketing-were-the-rats-and-facebook-likes-are-the-reward/276613/|website=The Atlantic|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=1 May 2015|ref=marketing}}</ref> for the way the companies use the ideas to keep users engaged and using the service.
[[Gamification]], the technique of using game design elements in non-game contexts, has also been described as using operant conditioning and other behaviorist techniques to encourage desired user behaviors.<ref>{{cite web |title=Slot machines perfected addictive gaming. Now, tech wants their tricks |first=Andrew |last=Thompson |date=6 May 2015 |publisher=[[The Verge]] |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/5/6/8544303/casino-slot-machine-gambling-addiction-psychology-mobile-games}}</ref>
==Skinner box== [[File:UNMSM PsiExperimental 1998 2.jpg|250px|thumb|Students using a Skinner box]] Skinner is noted to have said that he did not want to be an [[eponym]].<ref>Skinner, B. F. (1959). Cumulative record (1999 definitive ed.). Cambridge, MA: B.F. Skinner Foundation. p 620</ref> Further, he believed that [[Clark_L._Hull|Clark Hull]] and his Yale students coined the expression: Skinner stated he did not use the term himself, and went so far as to ask Howard Hunt to use "lever box" instead of "Skinner box" in a published document.<ref>Skinner, B. F. (1983). A Matter of Consequences. New York, NY: Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. p 116, 164</ref>
==See also== * [[Behaviorism]] * [[Radical behaviorism]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Use British English|date=December 2013}} '''Parity''' is a [[United Kingdom]]-based [[Equality before the law|equal rights]] organisation,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Campbell|first1=Dennis|title=More than 40% of domestic violence victims are male, report reveals|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=4 Sep 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150821020419/http://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/sep/05/men-victims-domestic-violence|archivedate=21 August 2015|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/sep/05/men-victims-domestic-violence|accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=<!--Staff writer-->|title='If I left her, I would be killed'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/health-11196907|accessdate=25 August 2015|work=[[BBC News]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150825151339/http://www.bbc.com/news/health-11196907|archivedate=25 August 2015}}</ref> which describes itself as campaigning to promote and protect the equality of men and women under the law.<ref name=autogenerated2>[http://www.parity-uk.org/ Parity - Campaigning for equal rights for UK men and women<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Its main focus has been in the area of state pensions and associated benefits, and most of its notable successes have occurred in this field. The organisation was previously called '''Campaign for Equal State Pension Ages'''.
{{Infobox non-profit | name = Parity | image = | type = [[Equality before the law|Equal rights]] charity | founded_date = 1986{{cn|date=June 2017}} | tax_id = | registration_id = 1107795 | founder = | location = 39 Cotton Road, [[Potters Bar]], EN6 5JT, Hertfordshire | origins = | key_people = David Yarwood (Hon Secretary) 29 August 1986 - 15 February 2015, Chandrakant Vaghela (Hon. Secretary - 15 February 2015 - present,{{cn|date=April 2018}} Chairpersons: David Lindsay 1986-91{{cn|date=June 2017}}; Maurice Oldfield 1991-98{{cn|date=June 2017}}; John Mays 1998 to present {{cn|date=April 2018}} | area_served = [[United Kingdom]] | product = | mission = ''To promote and protect the equal rights of men and women to the enjoyment of all civil, political, economic social and cultural rights under the law.'' | focus = [[Gender equality]], [[pensions]], [[domestic violence]], [[equal parenting]], [[education]], [[health]] | method = | revenue = £1,016 | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = Equal Rights for UK Men and Women | former name = Campaign for Equal State Pension Ages | homepage = [http://www.parity-uk.org/ parity-uk.org] | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
==History== Parity was formed in 1986 as the "Campaign for Equal State Pension Ages" (CESPA) <ref name=autogenerated4>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/2003998.stm BBC NEWS | Business | Threat to National Insurance increase<!-- Both generated title -->]</ref> and its principal aim was to obtain for men the same [state pension] age as enjoyed by women.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> The organisation changed its name to "Parity" in 1997 to reflect growing concern regarding increased unequal treatment of men and women in other areas by the state.<ref>[http://www.hertsdirect.org/comdirectory/comvol/trade2y/tdfina3y/pensions4/?view=Printlist hertsdirect.org Pensions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
CESPA's inaugural meeting was held on 29 August 1986 in Committee Room 1 of Manchester Town Hall. The ten founder members were G.W. Alderton, D.Higgins, D.J.D Yarwood, J.H Bennett, E.L Anderson, J.Greenwood, M.D Davidson, J.Graham, D.G Lindsay, and J. Bradfield. The original CESPA constitution was agreed. The meeting appointed David Lindsay as Chairman, Geoff Alderton as Vice-Chairman, David Yarwood as Hon Secretary and John Bennett as Treasurer.<ref>http://www.parity-uk.org/history_of_cespa1.php</ref>
Parity was denied charitable status for a number of years because it was seeking changes in the law to redress statutory [[sex discrimination]], and thus was deemed to be political.<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-912855991.html Parity & Equal rights for men - Mankind | HighBeam Research - FREE trial<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It finally gained [[Charitable organization#United Kingdom|charitable status]] in 2005 following a change to the [[Human Rights Act 1998|Human Rights Act]].<ref name=autogenerated2 />
==Organisation== The organisation is run entirely by volunteers and receives no public funding.<ref>[http://www.parity-uk.org/organisation.php Parity - Campaigning for equal rights for UK men and women<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It had an income of £1,016 in 2017.<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/PrintReport.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1107795&ReportType=BW Charity-commission.gov.uk]</ref>
In its constitution it states its objectives are "to promote and protect the equal rights of men and women to the enjoyment of all civil, political, economic social and cultural rights under the law" and "to institute proceedings in the UK or appropriate European Courts for the purpose of establishing or protecting any such equal rights."<ref>[http://www.parity-uk.org/index.php Parity - Campaigning for equal rights for UK men and women<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Achievements== Parity has had some notable successes over the years, particularly in addressing statutory sex discrimination. Their campaigns have stopped government [[sex discrimination]] which, in the case of winter fuel payments, had denied an estimated £20 million per year to males between the ages of 60-65.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/567208.stm BBC News | UK | Winter fuel payments 'sexist'<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Parity claims successes in four main areas: [[Prescription (medical)|prescription]] charges, winter fuel payments, [[Bus_pass#UK|bus travel concessions]] and, in association with others, [[widower]]'s benefits:
===Prescription charges=== Parity's first major success began in 1993 under its original name, when CESPA member Cyril Richardson, an [[asthmatic]], took the government to court over sex discrimination in entitlement for free [[Prescription drug|prescriptions]].<ref>[http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=16471 Equal rights for men at the chemist's - Article - TES Connect<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=autogenerated3>[http://www.parliament.uk/commons/lib/research/rp2001/rp01-080.pdf The Travel Concessions (Eligibility) Bill [HL] Bill 38 of 2001-02<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618214600/http://www.parliament.uk/commons/lib/research/rp2001/rp01-080.pdf |date=18 June 2009 }}</ref> Eventually, in 1995 the European Court of Justice ruled that it was unlawful to charge men aged 60–65 for prescriptions when they were free to women. As a result, men now receive benefits in the order of an estimated £30 million per annum. Additionally, £10 million in charges was refunded to those who had wrongly paid for prescriptions in the previous 3 months before the ruling.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Ay06C8wAdAAC&pg=PA705&lpg=PA705&dq=1995+nhs+prescription+charges+men&source=bl&ots=J7Ec4-rWx0&sig=K1uuQ8Ttlf3tWYz4EuM37bl9JHg&hl=en&ei=DoTiSf6MM8WhjAfT7bnUDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4 The textbook of pharmaceutical medicine - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/extract/311/7013/1118/a Men can have free prescriptions at 60 - 311 (7013): 1118 - bmj.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Winter fuel payments=== In 1998 Parity member John Taylor went to the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] to contest the fact that the government was denying [[winter fuel payment]]s to men aged 60–65 that women were able to receive. It was argued that this was a breach of European laws on equality in social security,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/189612.stm BBC News | UK | Winter fuel case goes to Europe<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and that such discrimination was blatant and unjustifiable.<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/winter-fuel-cash-cheats-men-says-court-chief-1121423.html Winter fuel cash cheats men, says court chief - News - The Independent<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The case was referred to the [[European Court of Justice]] who ruled in Mr Taylor's favour in December 1999.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> The ruling meant up to £26 million per annum in benefits being given to men that otherwise would have been denied.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/455023.stm BBC News | UK Politics | Fuel payments ruling due<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Bus travel concessions=== In 2000 Parity took the Government to the [[European Court of Human Rights]] over the fact that it denied [[free travel pass|free bus travel]] to men aged 60–65.<ref>[http://archive.thisisyork.co.uk/2000/4/28/317100.html Postman leads fight to change bus pass policy<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20070730222225/http://archive.thisisyork.co.uk/2000/4/28/317100.html |date=30 July 2007 }}</ref> Despite Parity's previous successes, the government had refused to end discrimination in this area.<ref name=autogenerated5>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/ministers-fight-free-bus-pass-for-men-at-60-634573.html Ministers fight free bus pass for men at 60 - UK Politics, UK - The Independent<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> However, in June 2001 it became clear that Parity would win the case if it went to court and the government relented, with [[John Prescott]] announcing men would receive free [[bus pass]]es from age 60. Controversially, Prescott hailed the move as "another example of the Government providing extra help for pensioners" whereas it had effectively been forced into the move by the European Court of Human Rights.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1323123/Men-over-60-to-be-eligible-for-free-bus-passes.html Men over 60 to be eligible for free bus passes - Telegraph<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The Travel Concessions (Eligibility) Bill finally passed in 2003 resulting in males receiving the £50 million per annum in benefits that the state had denied them.<ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/2880989.stm BBC NEWS | Business | End to 'sexist' bus fares<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Widowers benefits=== Parity campaigned to end sexism in the payment of widows benefits and bereavement tax allowances. These were previously only paid to women and not men. The campaign achieved success in 2001 as a result the benefits are now available to both genders.<ref name=autogenerated4 /><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/2002647.stm BBC NEWS | Business | Widowers besiege Europe with benefit claims<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Domestic violence statistics=== In 2008 Parity campaigned to stop the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] making false statements that the "overwhelming" majority of domestic violence victims were women, whereas in fact about one in three victims is male. With the aid of the [[UK Statistics Authority]] the organisation succeeded and the incorrect claims were removed.<ref>[http://www.statisticsauthority.gov.uk/reports---correspondence/correspondence/new-component.pdf Statisticsauthority.gov.uk]</ref><ref>[http://www.statisticsauthority.gov.uk/reports---correspondence/correspondence/letter-from-sir-roger-jowell-to-keir-starmer-qc-30-march-2009.pdf Statisticsauthority.gov.uk]</ref> The organisation also forced [[Gillian Morgan]] of the [[Welsh Assembly]] to stop making the same claims in the "Strategic Action Plan to Address Violence to Women".<ref>[http://www.statisticsauthority.gov.uk/reports---correspondence/correspondence/Copy_of_letter-from-sir-michael-scholar-to-dame-gillian-morgan-021009.pdf Statisticsauthority.gov.uk]</ref>
==Current campaigns== Parity's main current campaign is to equalise the state [[pension]] ages for men and women in the United Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.parity-uk.org/successes.php Parity - Campaigning for equal rights for UK men and women<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Currently this is now due to take place in 2018.
Other objectives include:<ref>[http://www.parity-uk.org/objectives.php Parity - Campaigning for equal rights for UK men and women<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
*Equal state funding for treatment and research of [[Sex and illness|male and female specific diseases]]. *Equal liability for men and women over 60 for [[National Insurance]] contributions. *Equal treatment of male and female victims of [[domestic violence]]. *Better government policies to ensure a more equal gender balance in [[primary school]] teaching and to boost the academic achievements of working class white children. *Funding for research into [[Life_expectancy#Gender_differences|life expectancy]] inequalities between men and women. *Equal status for separated parents and better enforcement of [[Contact (law)|contact]] and maintenance orders. *Equal anonymity for defendants and complainants in [[sex offence]] cases until conviction.
==Supporters== Parity's present patrons are Sir [[Peter Bottomley]] MP and Mr Mark Brooks.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.parity-uk.org/ Official Parity Website]

revision.comment: In the statement that "a posetal category corresponds to an inconsistent theory", I added the qualifier "codiscrete", as it is required for it to be true.
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2016}} In [[mathematics]], a '''posetal category''', or '''thin category''',<ref>{{nlab|id=thin+category|title=Thin category}}</ref> is a [[Category (mathematics)|category]] whose [[Category (mathematics)#Small and large categories|homsets]] each contain at most one morphism. As such, a posetal category amounts to a [[preordered class]] (or a [[preordered set]], if its objects form a set). As suggested by the name, the further requirement that the category be [[Skeleton (category theory)|skeletal]] is often assumed for the definition of "posetal"; in the case of a category that is posetal, being skeletal is equivalent to the requirement that the only isomorphisms are the identity morphisms, equivalently that the preordered class satisfies [[antisymmetry]] and hence, if a set, is a [[poset]].
All [[diagram (category theory)|diagram]]s [[commutative diagram|commute]] in a posetal category. When the commutative diagrams of a category are interpreted as a typed equational theory whose objects are the types, a codiscrete posetal category corresponds to an inconsistent theory understood as one satisfying the axiom ''x'' = ''y'' at all types.
Viewing a [[2-category]] as an [[enriched category]] whose hom-objects are categories, the hom-objects of any extension of a posetal category to a [[2-category]] having the same 1-cells are [[monoid]]s.
Some lattice-theoretic structures are definable as posetal categories of a certain kind, usually with the stronger assumption of being skeletal. For example, a poset may be defined as a posetal category, a [[distributive lattice]] as a posetal [[distributive category]], a [[Heyting algebra]] as a posetal finitely [[cocomplete]] [[cartesian closed category]], and a [[Boolean algebra]] as a posetal finitely cocomplete [[*-autonomous category]]. Conversely, categories, distributive categories, finitely cocomplete cartesian closed categories, and finitely cocomplete *-autonomous categories can be considered the respective [[categorification]]s of posets, distributive lattices, Heyting algebras, and Boolean algebras.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Category theory]]

revision.comment: A Running Start - Apollo 17 up to Powered Descent Initiation ref
revision.text:
'''Powered Descent Initiation (PDI)''' is a term used during the [[Apollo program]] [[Moon landing]] missions to describe the maneuver of the [[Apollo Lunar Module]] as it descended from [[lunar orbit]] to landing. <ref>[https://www.hq.nasa.gov/alsj/a17/a17.prepdi.html A Running Start - Apollo 17 up to Powered Descent Initiation]</ref>
"''Eagle'' was GO to ignite its descent engine, and [[Neil Armstrong|Armstrong]] and [[Buzz Aldrin|Aldrin]] locked their eyes to the glowing numbers displayed before them. They were almost at an invisible junction of height, speed, range, and time when everything would join together for commitment. When the instruments told them that they were 192 miles from their projected landing site, and were precisely 50,174 radar~measured feet above the long shadows of the moon, they would unleash decelerating thrust and begin slowing their speed for the touchdown.....this was it. PDI. Powered Descent Initiate."<ref>Moon Shot The Inside Story of America's Race to the Moon, Alan Shepard/Deke Slayton Page 17 First Edition</ref>
